thread.title_full: Alaska Airlines' Mileage Plan lands top spot in loyalty program rankings

author: Harriet Baskas, Special for USA TODAY
title: Alaska Airlines' Mileage Plan lands top spot in loyalty program rankings
text:
Alaska Airlines' Mileage Plan took the top spot on U.S. News & World Report's list of Best Airline Reward Programs. (Photo: Elaine Thompson, AP)
Tags Jetblue Airways American Airlines 40 CONNECT 43 TWEET 16 LINKEDIN 1 COMMENT EMAIL MORE U.S. News & World Report, which ranks everything from colleges to hospitals, today released its annual rankings of airline and hotel loyalty programs.
For the first time, Alaska Airlines’ Mileage Plan took the top spot on the list of Best Airline Reward Programs, thanks to high marks for elite membership benefits, ease of earning free round-trip flights, and network coverage.
Ten frequent flier programs tied to U.S.-based airlines were included in the U.S. News & World Report 2015-16 Best Travel Rewards Programs rankings and were evaluated using methodology that looks at each program's earning and redemption values, benefits, network coverage and award flight availability.
American Airlines’ AAdvantage Program, Southwest’s Rapid Rewards, JetBlue’s True Blue and Hawaiian Airlines’ Hawaiian Miles program also ranked in the top five this year, in that order.

To rank the programs, U.S. News and World Report uses a scoring algorithm.
A large part of an airline’s overall score (45% weight) is based on the ease of earning miles or points and the ease with which travelers can redeem them.
Twenty-five percent weight is given to the ways — other than booking flights — in which travelers can earn points, the additional perks that come from membership and whether or not points expire.
Ten percent weight is given to the range of routes offered by each airline and its alliance network (how far can you go on your points) and another 10% weight is allotted to award flight availability. The number of daily flights and the Airline Quality Rating score are also taken into consideration.
“Many travel loyalty programs come with a string of caveats, making it challenging to maximize your rewards," Liz Weiss, travel editor for U.S. News & World Report, said in a statement. "Our rankings highlight the programs that make it easy to earn free flights or hotel stays and offer plenty of reward options and perks travelers value, such as upgrades, free checked bags and priority boarding access."

You can see the full list of rankings, along with scoring breakouts and helpful pros and cons for each airline reward program that was evaluated, here .
Curious about the hotel side of the rankings ? Marriott Rewards lands in the top spot for the third year in a row, followed by Wyndham Rewards, Best Western Rewards and Club Carlson — which tied for third place — and the IHG Rewards Club.
Harriet Baskas is a Seattle-based airports and aviation writer and USA TODAY Travel's " At the Airport " columnist. She occasionally contributes to Ben Mutzabaugh's Today in the Sky blog. Follow her at twitter.com/hbaskas .
